text:
Thanks, Mark, for
the introduction and for inviting me
to come out here. It's a great
pleasure to be here.

Yeah. So my talk today
will be on contact. And overall, in my lab, we're
working on getting robots

to work in the real world. And that's thinking about
challenging outdoor terrain, deserts, forests,
that kind of thing,

as well as messy
human environments. We do less in the warehouse,
factory kind of space.

And some of the applications
we're looking at include things like
planetary exploration stuff. We have a big project here
in environmental monitoring.

So sending a robot
out specifically to look for
contaminants in soils, like asbestos, or mercury, or
lead, or that kind of thing

with mobile robots
that are digging and playing around in the dirt. All right.

So if we want robots to get
out into the real world, what's the challenge? Why is this a hard problem?

And so this was the video that
was playing at the beginning. This is a blooper reel of
taking some legged robots out

to the park behind campus. And in each of these clips,
what I want you to take away

is that the problem was that
there was unexpected contact with the world. Either it tried to
put its foot down

and there was nothing
there, or, here, it's touching these vines that
it doesn't know anything about.

Maybe it's got a camera
or a laser scanner. You can see the
top of this plant, but it's not going to see
the ground that it's actually

stepping on, and it's not going
to be able to pick out the vine that it's hooked on. So all of these-- either
it's bumping into something

it doesn't know about or it's
trying to touch something and missing. And this is a challenge not just
for robots, but also humans.

So here's a YouTube video from
a subway stair in New York City that over
time has settled so

that one step is slightly taller
than all of the other steps. And everyone that
goes by, they're

taking their legs
over the stair. They think they can clear the
stair, and they can't quite.

And that one little
tiny bump on your foot causes you to trip, right?

So this challenge with
contact with the world being different than you
expect is a big problem.

It also comes up
in manipulation. So here's another
blooper reel of trying to pick up little objects. And again, all of
these, I think,

come down to either the
friction is a little different than we thought, or
we bump into it early,

or it just whiffs and
slightly misses the contact that it's trying to make.

So most of the
projects in my lab fall into these
two key challenges,

the first being contact, and
in particular the discontinuous nature of contact. So when your foot
is on the ground,

you have large contact forces. And when your foot is a
millimeter above the ground, you get no contact force.

And that discontinuity
causes a lot of problems. All of our traditional
state estimation, control,

learning all of these
things, at some level, assume continuous, if not
smooth or something stronger,

in our dynamics. And then the second key
challenge is uncertainty. So maybe we can have a
good model of a robot,

but we're not going to have
a good model of how squishy that pile of leaves is,
or what's the friction

coefficient on this rock. And so rather than trying to do
better and better perception,

and get a perfect
model of the world, and learn a perfect
dynamics model-- I don't think that's possible
for what we're doing.

And so we want to
instead come up with approaches that
don't need a perfect model and can handle this kind
of large uncertainty

that we're going to have. So then with these
kind key themes

of contact and uncertainty, and
looking towards getting robots out into challenging
environments,

we work on all
areas of robotics. So we do controls. We do design. We do some learning and vision.

And today, I'm going to
mostly talk about stuff more on the control side. And in particular, I'm going
to spend the first half

or so to maybe 2/3 talking about
techniques for using what I call

hybrid dynamical systems and
one way to model contacts,

and then-- with certain assumptions. And then in the
last third I'll talk about examples that break
all of those assumptions,

and we'll see where
that doesn't hold. So when do these hybrid
models work well?

So the hybrid system, the
hybridness, the word "hybrid" there means that it's a
combination of continuous state and discrete state.

And for us, that's going to
be-- discrete state is going to be our contact conditions. So touching and not
touching, as well as things

like stick and slip friction. And so for robots
like in these videos,

this kind of hybrid
model works pretty well. And what I say is, if you can
take a video of your robot, play it back, maybe
play it back slow,

but if you can watch
the video and say, ah, here's where it's touching,
here's where it's not, here's where it's touching, then
this kind of hybrid system model

is a good approximation. And that covers a lot of what we
do in robotics with manipulation

and locomotion tasks. It's not everything. So here's a bunch
of examples where

I think these kinds
of hybrid models that I'm going to talk
about don't work well. And so things like interacting
with fabric, where there's not

this kind of discrete contact,
no contact; and then sand, where it's this
continually flowing media.

We're not going to
slow down this video and look at the
particles of sand and look at, when are they
touching, when are they not

touching, right? So for all of these examples,
the hybrid system models

that I'm talking about
in the first half maybe aren't a
good approximation. And we'll cover some of
this stuff near the end.

So the first thing
I want to talk about is trying to do
state estimation, trying to understand what
our state is in the world

when we have these kind of
contacts in a hybrid system framework. And the most basic fundamental
state estimation algorithm

is Kalman filtering. And so if it's been
a minute since you've done Kalman filtering, or even
if you're very familiar, just

to get us all on the same
page, here's a quick rundown. So in Kalman
filtering, we're going to have some estimate
of our state--

that's the blue
dot in the middle-- and then we'll have some
covariance, some uncertainty around that state.

And there's two steps
in Kalman filtering. The first step, we're
going to propagate that forward and predict where
we'll be at the next time step.

So that involves
taking our dynamics and moving our estimate
forward in time, as well

as our covariance, and seeing
how our covariance will grow or shrink over time. And in particular, we
usually add some extra noise.

So the covariance
is typically going to grow over time as we become-- as we get farther and farther
from our initial condition.

Then to reduce our
uncertainty, to become more certain about
where our state is,

we'll take some measurement. So there's some sensor. Maybe we can see
that little feature in the corner of the slide.

And based on our sensor
model, we say, all right. That means I'm
probably over here, but there's some
noise in the sensor.

So there's some
uncertainty there. And Kalman filtering
tells us the best way to combine these two
estimates into a new best

estimate of our
state and covariance based on our prior
and our measurement.

All right. So that's like a whole
lecture's worth of controls 101 in one slide.

So if we want to do this
kind of state estimation with a hybrid
system, so now we're going to impact the ground.

So I'll explain this in that
first step, the prediction step. But it's pretty similar if we
do it in the measurement step

as well. But let's say somewhere
along that time, our foot hits the ground, or our
hand touches an object.

When we updated our mean
in this continuous regime, we applied our dynamics,
and then our covariance

was propagated with the
Jacobian of the dynamics. So this is the A
matrix in controls.

And so when we get
to an impact, we have a model of that impact,
which I'll call the reset map.

But this is your plastic
impact, elastic impact. We have some forward prediction
of how the velocity will change

when we impact an object. And so we can use that
to update our mean.

And then for the
covariance, we might think that we could use the
Jacobian of the reset map, so the Jacobian of
our impact dynamics,

to update that covariance. And this turns out not to work. And to see why, I'm
going to show here

a very simple hybrid system. So picture on the left is
kind of my leg is in the air, and on the right is my leg
is touching the ground.

In this case, the
dynamics on the left are constant vector field. So everything's just
moving down into the right.

And on the right, we have
a constant vector field slightly up and to the right. In the middle would
be that impact time.

And in this case, I'm
showing that there's no jump. So the reset map
itself is an identity.

So there's no change in
state at the boundary. So on the left,
constant velocity.

So that means nothing's
growing or shrinking. On the right, constant velocity.

Nothing's growing or shrinking. And in the middle, we
have an identity function. Nothing's changing
at the middle.

So nothing changes on the left. Nothing changes on the right. Nothing changes in the middle. And yet, as our distribution
of-- or sort of uncertain state

here goes through
this transition, the covariance is changing. It's getting stretched out.

And so if we just
used the Jacobian of our impact of our
reset map, then we

would say that the
covariance at the end should match the covariance
at the beginning, which is the red circle.

And so that doesn't
capture this at all. So how can we make-- how can we propagate
our covariance

through this kind of transition? And the key tool that
we need to do this is called the saltation matrix.

And it basically
maps, if there's some displacement or
variance before an impact,

how does that translate
to a variance afterwards? And the formula for it--

you can ignore the details. But basically, the
saltation matrix, it starts with that
Jacobian of the reset map.

So we do need to know the
derivatives of what that impact dynamics are. And then there's
all this other junk.

And what's over here, again,
the details aren't important, but it's like the
dynamics in our new mode. The dynamics in the old mode,
what that boundary looks like,

as well as time derivatives
of all these things. And I'll be honest. The first time I saw
this equation, I said,

this is way too messy. There's no way
this is important. It's this big ugly thing. You need a million
little terms to compute.

How is this useful? But it turns out
that you really do need to account for all of this.

And what these extra terms are
doing is accounting for the fact that if you're a little
bit ahead or a little

bit behind of the
nominal trajectory, you're going to spend
more time in one mode versus the other mode.

And so this is accounting for
that difference in impact timing that then leads to that
of skewing we saw before.

And so after realizing that this
is actually very important--

I mean, it's been known for-- I think the earliest place that
we've seen this show up was somewhere in the '50s.

So it's not that
this matrix is new, but we're applying
it in new ways

and bringing it to the
robotics community. So to help with that, we wrote
this survey tutorial thing

in proceedings of the
IEEE that just came out-- so if you're coming
out of this and say,

I guess I need to
think about this, hopefully we've written like a
nice, gentle introduction to it

so that you're not just stuck
staring at this ugly equation. All right. So with this saltation
matrix thing,

now, if we want to
propagate our covariance, if this is our initial
covariance, we can map it.

Over here on the
right, in black, is the actual covariance
of this set of particles.

And then in yellow dash is the
saltation matrix prediction, which is exact in this
kind of linear case.

So now we can update
our covariance estimates through these kinds
of transitions.

And so we can put this back
into our Kalman filter. So now our continuous
predictions,

when we're not impacting
anything, nothing has changed. This is just like a
regular Kalman filter or extended Kalman filter.

And then when we
have an impact event, we apply our reset dynamics,
so our impact law, to the mean,

but then we use this saltation
matrix to update the covariance. And that ends up being
the key to getting

state estimation for these
kinds of hybrid systems. So what does this look like? So if we try and do state
estimation and track our state

through this two-phase system-- I call this the
cheese grater system,

sort of sliding through that
middle line in the middle. What we see here, this is
the error in our estimate.

If we just use that
Jacobian of the reset map, we get much higher error. And then if we use
this saltation matrix,

we get pretty good
tracking on that. And a couple of things to note. Before the impact--
so the impact happens

or the transition happens
somewhere in the middle here. Before that, it's
exactly the same,

because it's just a
Kalman filter other than at the time of impact.

And then afterwards,
it's better. There's still a little bit-- we're not quite as good as
the best possible estimate

right around the
impact, and that's because this is still a
local linear approximation.

So we're still saying
that the mean either has transitioned or
not transitioned,

and we move all of the
probability across at once. And so that's one
limitation here

that we might want to
improve eventually. But once we've gotten all the
way through the transition,

we have the correct
estimate for the covariates. We can apply this to
more complicated systems.

So here, this is an
asymmetric SLIP hopper, so like a legged hopping robot,
with six states and nonlinear.

And this one actually
has a jump at the impact, where the last one, there
was no actual impact law.

And here, if we compare again,
blue is this saltation matrix thing, and red is
if we just take

the Jacobian of the reset map. It actually looks pretty similar
in every dimension except one.

So here in y, so in
the vertical direction, we're getting much better
state estimate tracking,

and that's because the
saltation matrix is actually-- it's a rank 1 update. It's just correcting in
the direction of the guard,

because it's that time
to impact difference. It's only in the direction of
the normal vector of your guard.

We're going to have a
much better estimate because we're counting for
variances in that direction.

So we can extend this now to-- we've extended it
to when we're not certain about exactly where
that transition happens.

So here, instead of
just a solid line, there's this gray set of lines. Each particle has a randomly
sampled transition point.

So now, if we aren't sure
exactly how high the ground is, or what the surface
normal is, we

can account for that
uncertainty as well. We're working now on
maintaining belief in multiple different modes.

But this works really well in
terms of just state estimation. And then this idea of
how do we propagate

covariance through
this transition, we can do the dual problem. So the dual to state
estimation would be control.

And so if we want to do
trajectory optimization or model predictive control, we
can use the same idea

in an iLQR-based
trajectory optimization. So in iLQR, you have to
propagate your gradients

backwards, propagate
your value function. And just like with
the covariance,

when you go through
this transition, you need to use the saltation
matrix to propagate that appropriately.

And so with that, this is
comparing a standard model predictive controller with
this hybrid iLQR model

predictive controller. And we hit the
robot, and then it's able to come up with a new
set of footfall conditions.

So one of the nice things
that comes out of this is that it's able to change
those contact timings

and change those contact
sequences to come up with a better way to catch
itself after a disturbance.

We've run this on the
actual robot as well. Here, to get a
consistent disturbance,

we just turn off the
motors for 150 milliseconds and let it fall and then
try and catch itself.

And again, this standard
model predictive controller gets totally lost because
it thinks all of the legs are off of the ground.

But with this iLQR model
predictive controller, it can say, oh, I need
to put my feet back down

and catch myself from there. So this saltation matrix helps
with both state estimation

and control techniques. The next thing I
want to talk about is stability and
analyzing behavior.

And maybe we're coming up with
a controller or maybe we're not. And for this, I'm going to
go through three examples

of heuristic controllers,
heuristic properties that we've seen in the past.

And I'll show how they're
all related and how, in fact, all of them use
the same saltation matrix to capture them.

So I'm going to go
through three examples. The first example
is a paddle juggler. So picture you've got a tennis
racket and a tennis ball,

and you're bouncing
the tennis ball, and you're trying to bounce it
to maybe a consistent height, all right?

Now, the dynamics of this-- so your control input is
just moving the paddle.

And so you're really
only affecting the ball at the moment
of impact, all right? And the dynamics
for that impact,

say that depends on the
velocity of the ball and the velocity of the paddle. So it matters the
position and the velocity

that we impact the ball with. It turns out, to
stabilize this, if you want to bounce it at a stable
height and with stable timing,

you need to impact it
with a nominal velocity, but with a negative
acceleration.

You need to be decelerating
as you come up. And the intuition
behind this is,

if the ball has too much
energy, it'll go higher. So it'll take longer.

And so when it
comes back down, you want to be going slower so that
you don't impart more energy. You want to take
some energy out.

If there's not enough
energy, it'll impact early. It's going to be going faster. So you want to be decelerating
as you impact the ball.

But what's interesting
is that the dynamics don't have the acceleration
term in them at all.

So where does this acceleration
property come from? So you see this acceleration.

This is a little confusing. So let me talk you through it. Here, we have three
paddles, red, yellow green.

They all hit the nominal ball. So the nominal
trajectory is in black. They all hit it at the same
position and the same velocity,

but they have
different acceleration. So one is x-- green one is decelerating.

The red one is accelerating. And the yellow one is going
at a constant velocity. But again, they're all
hitting at the nominal time,

same position, same velocity. So they all hit the black
ball, and the black ball will do the same
thing for all of them.

So the green paddle
hits the green ball. The red one hits the red balls. And we see that this cloud of--

if we have a little bit of
noise in our initial condition-- all of the red, green, and
yellow started out similarly.

Here, those green balls slowly
get closer and closer and closer to the nominal trajectory,
while the red ones

kind of explode, and the yellow
ones are somewhere in between. They kind of stay spread
out, but they're not getting

bigger or smaller uncertainty. All right. So this result that
for paddle juggling

you need to be decelerating
when you impact has been known for
a while actually.

So here's a paper from
Schaal and Atkeson from 1993 where they show this. And at the top, you can see
it's accelerating upwards.

And the very small
initial uncertainty grows to larger and larger.

At the bottom,
we're decelerating, and it's converging to-- even with a pretty large
initial uncertainty,

converges to a
single trajectory. All right. So that's example 1,
is paddle juggling.
Yeah. Yeah. Does the actual value matter? So I thought it's negative. I thought it decelerates.

It will have this
stabilizing property. Yeah. There's a range of values
where it's actually,

I think, equally stabilizing. And it matters more in terms of
how far away from the nominal--

because if you're decelerating
very quickly, all of a sudden, you'll be going the
wrong direction.

And so if you're really
far from the nominal, then that'll start to come in. Yeah.

All right. So that was example 1. Example 2, swing-leg retraction. So if you've ever done
anything with legged locomotion

or human locomotion, you
may be familiar with this. So when you walk, you
swing your leg forward.

And then you don't want that-- you don't want to
scuff your foot, right? So the first thing you
do is you slow the foot

down to try and get
it to be roughly the same speed as the ground. And you would think
that the optimal would

be what people call ground speed
matching, that we would want no relative velocity
because then we don't

have any tangential impulse. That's not quite what we do. We swing our leg
forward, and then it

starts to come back
just a little bit. And so that's what this is
showing here, in the stripes,

is this velocity backwards. And afterwards, as
you're walking away--

you can try and think about
if you're actually doing this. If you get a high-speed
video, you can watch,

and you'll see you really do
actually swing your leg back ever so slightly. And the reason is that it
improves your stability.

So I mean, this is an eye chart,
but the number of stable points increases as the speed of
this retraction increases.

So if we swing
our leg backwards, we get stable locomotion.

Here's a little
bit of a tangent. Before I explain the
robot, let's just watch this walking robot. As it swings its leg forward,
the forward motion stops,

and it's just
starting to come back when the leg hits the ground. All right. So here's one example of this.

I bring this up-- so this is
a very simple biped design. We call this Mugatu.

But I think this is the simplest
walking robot we can have. So this is one motor and two
rigid bodies, the left leg

and a right leg. And the arms are bolted
to the opposite leg,

but we're still able
to get stable walking. It can start, stop,
turn left, turn right through careful design
of the passive dynamics

and timing of the
control on the one motor. So this guy was pretty cool.

This was at Humanoids last year. And I'll be honest,
I didn't know

that the Humanoids people
would think that this is a humanoid enough for them. But we got it in.

Certainly, it's got
two legs, but I don't know if it's humanoid for them. So this was about, I'm going to
say, 13 centimeters, maybe 15.

I forget. About yay big leg length. So it's also pretty small. And as a sneak peek here, here's
our 2 and 1/2-centimeter leg
version. Same idea. One motor, two rigid bodies. So this is submitted to ICRA.

So hopefully, you'll see
more of this next summer. All right. Sorry, we got on
this little tangent

with these cute
little walking robots. We were talking about
swing-leg retraction. All right. So that was our second example.

Our third example is going
to be the Raibert heuristic. So if you have a
hopping robot and you

want to control
the forward speed, you can control that by
changing the angle at which you

impact the ground. So if this is your
nominal impact,

if you come in at
a shallower angle, then your leg is going
to slow you down. If you come in at
a steeper angle,

then you're going to
fall over your stance leg and you'll accelerate forward. So again, there's some
nominal angle where

your forward acceleration is 0. Less than that,
you're decelerating. And yeah less than that--

so they're measuring this way-- you're accelerating. And then if you're shallower,
then you're decelerating.

And Marc Raibert,
just he's a genius. He just looked at his
robots and figured this out.

And so this is
from a 1984 paper,

possibly even before then. So here's a video of his leg lab
at Carnegie Mellon at the time,

I'll point out. And so that's how these
early hopping robots were able to walk stably.

And you could sit
there with a joystick and say, go faster or go slower. And it's using this leg angle
control to change that speed.

All right. So the example 2 and
example 3, if you take your swing-leg retraction
as well as this Raibert

heuristic, you get
stable hopping. So here on the left, if we just
have a nominal touchdown angle--

and here, at the
beginning of the video, it's kind of hard to see, but
there's 10 slightly ghosted--

you almost can't even
tell that they're different ones initially. And after-- it
doesn't take long.

It's like two or three steps. They start flying off
all over the place. It's actually pretty unstable.

But if we have this Raibert
heuristic for our forward speed and a swing-leg
retraction on the timing,
we get stable hopping motion. So we had three examples.

It was the paddle juggler,
the Raibert heuristic, and the swing-leg retraction. And all of these kind
of had a character of we

were changing what we were
doing around the impact time. And somehow, that affected the
stability of the whole system.

And it turns out that this
saltation matrix pops up again. So the way we can describe these
systems, if we think about--

if there was some
uncertainty at the beginning, if we go through the whole
cycle and come back around,

the way that maps
onto some error at the end or some
uncertainty at the end

is called the monodromy matrix. And the way that's built
for a hybrid system is this saltation
matrix term shows up

any time you have an impact, and
then this A matrix for any time you have continuous phase. And you have this intersplicing
of your continuous dynamics,

your saltation matrix,
continuous dynamics, saltation matrix. If we change something
about our impact,

like we change
that acceleration, that parameter doesn't show up
in any of these other terms.

It only shows up in
this one term here. So we can analyze the
stability of the whole system just by changing this
one term in this matrix.

And again, this
saltation matrix thing turns out-- pops out pretty
ugly, but describes all three

of those examples. And now we can apply
the same idea of what

we call hybrid event shaping. We can change what's happening
around the time of impact to improve our stability.

We can apply that to
any hybrid system. So as an example, here, we're
doing this five-link biped

walker. So it has motors at
the hip and knee. The knee also has
a hard stop to--

so that there's an
impact at the hard stop and there's an impact
with the ground. And in this example,
we're actually

doing no continuous
time feedback. So we're not doing any kind
of LQR, learning, nothing.

We're only controlling
this by changing the shape of these hybrid events
around a nominal open-loop

trajectory. And so if you just do a
trajectory optimization to find a limit cycle,
so find a stable--

or a walking gait where you end
up where you started, and you try and minimize
the total energy,

so the minimum
energy trajectory, after like three
steps, you blow up.

If you have any amount of
uncertainty in your state, that'll grow pretty quickly,
and you'll fall over.

Again, we're doing no
continuous time feedback. There's no sensing. So it's not too surprising
that this unsensed humanoid

is going to fall over. But if we do this
hybrid event shaping-- and we have two versions here.

But again, basically,
it's things like that swing-leg retraction,
Raibert heuristic kind of stuff. But generalized to
this arbitrary system,

we can get stable
walking indefinitely with no continuous
time feedback.

Now, I think you should also
do continuous time feedback. I'm not saying we shouldn't
have feedback control.

But now, our feedback
control doesn't have to do nearly as much work. And so one of the
things moving forward,

we've now combined this
in an iLQR framework. So we're doing both
iLQR to get an LQR

controller, a continuous
time feedback controller, as well as considering these
kind of stability properties

around our impact and
actually throughout the rest of the trajectory. And so here, for this
four-legged hopping example,

if we don't do this and
we just do regular iLQR, it kind of diverges
after one hop.

But here, we're able
to shape those impacts and get a stable
hopping behavior.

So again, the key idea
here in this section was that by looking at these
saltation matrices again,

we can look at
stability properties, just analyzing them at
the moment of impact,

which is kind of cool. One place that we're trying to
apply this stability analysis

is doing things like
walking on narrow beams. So I mean, the quadrupeds
are pretty stable.

So we've got to challenge them. So we're going to make it
walk on a really narrow beam. And we're looking at
different walking behaviors.

And one of the interesting
that popped out of this was that the gait pattern. So whether it's a walking
one-leg-at-a-time or a trotting

two-legs-at-a-time motion, we
thought that would be pretty predictive of the stability.

That actually doesn't
seem to matter too much. The only thing that really
matters is the duty factor, so the percent of time
each leg is on the ground.

And the phasing between
the legs was less important for stability.

But in any case, this is
using that same analysis.

So I've done a bunch
of stuff talking about these hybrid
system models of contact for state estimation,
control, stability analysis.

And again, this
works great if, when you watch the video
of your robot, you can say, oh, here's
where we're touching,

and here's where
we're not touching. So let's move on
to these messier, more challenging things, where
these hybrid systems, everything

I just said doesn't
really apply anymore. So what happens in these cases?

And let's really think about
what was this hybrid model-- what were the assumptions
that went into that?

So the four main
assumptions that are baked into this, first of
all, first was plastic impact.

And actually, I think plastic
impact is almost always what we want in robotics.

So that paddle juggling,
we needed elastic impact. But for the most part with my
robot, if I go touch something,

I want to keep touching it. I don't want to bounce
off of it, right? And so actually,
I've done some stuff

where plastic
impact wasn't enough and I made something
that was more plastic than plastic impact.

But in any case, plastic
impact was one assumption. We assumed that there
were no adhesive forces. So the ground pushes
up on a robot.

It doesn't pull us
into the ground. That contact is
rigid, so it enforces

like a velocity constraint
or an acceleration constraint between, say, your
foot in the ground

or your hand in the object. And finally, the contact
doesn't change the surface,

doesn't change the
thing you're touching. And so the state-- if we
want to describe the system, we just need to know
where, in this case,

the height of the ball is. There's no state in the ground. We don't need to know
the height of the ground. That's constant.

So of these, I would say
the top two are pretty easy.

We can relax these in this kind
of hybrid system framework. Still works pretty well. And the bottom two
are a little harder.

So let me go through
a few quick examples, and we'll look at all of these. So the first one is, let's
look at adhesive forces.

So this is a magnetic
wall-climbing robot. And so now, we stick
to the wall right?

We get a force into the wall. And this still fits into this
kind of hybrid system framework.

So nominally, we would say, our
normal force has to be positive.

Now, it's just offset. Now, it needs to be greater than
some magnetic adhesion force. But otherwise, structurally,
everything works out the same.

And this was a neat
design that was very good at doing these kind of
floor-to-wall, wall-to-ceiling

transitions. And there in the middle, the
yellow thing in the middle, is called a PXRF, Portable
X-ray Fluorescence, sensor.

So we can make these
transitions and then scan for contaminants on
the surface as we're going.

All right. So adhesive forces. There's another kind
of adhesive force we've used for microspines.

So a lot of this comes out
of Marc's lab originally. And for microspines, there
are these little fish hooks

that grab onto little
bumps on the rocks. And here, you see there's
these 10 red fingers.

Each one is
individually compliant and has its own little fishhook.

So the individual
compliance is important because they have to maybe
stretch to different lengths so that each of them can grab
onto its own little bump.

But then if you do that, you
get enough of them to hook on, and you can grab on to
the rock and climb up.

Here, the microspine, instead of
our normal force being greater

than 0, we have this
other kind of formula that approximates what
forces are allowed. It kind of looks like a
friction [? cone, ?] but it's

a little different. But again, it still fits
well within this framework of hybrid systems.

We just have a slightly
different contact model at the base of it. So with these microspines,
we can make climbing robots.

So this was our LORIS robot that
we presented at ICRA this year

that can do cinderblock, or
slag, or other kinds of rocks.

This was my only student who was
excited to be in a cinderblock office.

This was his office, actually,
where he filmed this. We've gotten them out of
that ugly office before.

And then this one's funny. We were trying to
get a bunch of rocks to build a wall in the lab.

And we're in Pittsburgh. And slag is this
byproduct of steelmaking.

They normally have to
pay to get rid of it and store it somewhere. And so if you show up
with a truck and say, hey,

can we have some slag? They were like,
yes, by all means. So we got a free slag wall
out of that, which was good.

And it turns out to be
great for climbing on. All right. So those are the easy
things to change.

Let's get into the things that
really break these hybrid system assumptions.

And so the first
will be vegetation. So we looked at this earlier. Let's say we're walking
through, and we're

getting hooked on
these vines, all right? As I'm watching this
video, I don't know

when it's touching what, right? We can't kind of tell, oh, we're
touching this vine at this time

and that vine at that time. And even if we could, I don't
have a model of those vines.

I don't know their stiffness. I don't know how
extensible they are.

And I don't want to. I don't want to
try and model that. So how are we going
to make progress

in this, where we have contact
with the world with large amount of uncertainty,
both in the model

and in the state
that we have here? And so our approach,
there's two parts to it.

The first is we use what's
called a link momentum observer to tell when
we've hit something.

And so this is taking-- we know how much torque
we apply to the leg. We know the dynamics
of the leg when

it's not touching something. So we know what the momentum
should be nominally.

And then if it's not that, there
must be some external force. And if that force is
higher than some threshold,

we'll say that
we've hit something. But we haven't figured
out where we're hitting or what we're hitting.

So then the second half is we
need a reactive controller. And here, in this
simulation, we're showing each of these
pluses is a vine

that it could get caught on. And we're going to come
up with a control strategy

where whatever is touching
us, anywhere on our leg, we'll come up with a strategy to
push that to the edge of the leg

and get over. So now, we don't need to
localize that contact, and we come up with a way to
get through it wherever it is.

And we also don't need to have
a perfect model of the forces, or the stiffness, or any
of that kind of stuff.

And so this works well
on a variety of things. So here, we're showing
a low stiffness. This is a bungee cord.

There is a stiff rope. Here, this is a rigid
beam, like a metal plate. And then this one is some
kind of robot torture

device that has all of those
things put together in sequence.

And so again, here
it's just sensing, hey, something-- my leg's not moving
the way I thought it should.

So let me do this reactive
behavior and get over it.

Yeah. [INAUDIBLE] So can you apply
this method to the earlier hybrid model scenario?

Will it just work
for those as well? Yeah. Yeah. You can definitely do
this kind of stuff for--

yeah, for rigid, plastic
impact kind of contact as well, certainly. And we have done that. And there, you
can get even more.

So we've done stuff
where you can actually localize where on
your leg you're

touching, if you assume that
the thing you're touching isn't moving. If the thing you're
touching is also moving,

then it's really hard
to figure out both where and what you're touching. Yeah.

And so it worked

predictive control that

where, all right, we're

is moving, and piling up,

of the Viper test rigs.

In this case, we told this
motor to pretend that it was broken and stuck, all right?

So if we send this to the moon
and one of the motors dies, how can we continue
to make progress?

Can we survive that
kind of failure? And what do we want to
do with the other wheels to compensate for that?

So to look at this, we built
up a terramechanics model,

looking at stress and friction
along the surface, both of the wheel as well as
the side of the wheel,

and we ran a bunch of
wheels through sandboxes to collect a bunch of data.

And long story short,
our model, which is the line, kind of
lines up with the dots,

which are the
experiments over here. So with this, we can now--
we can make predictions about wheels that
are doing things

that are very different
than standard driving. So this is now over-- compared to previous
models, we can

handle a wide range of angles-- so we have the wheel stuck
at some weird angle-- as well as slip ratios.

So you can have one
wheel spinning backwards and the other three spinning
forward and still get pretty good force predictions.

And it's a pretty quick
model to evaluate. So we don't have to simulate
a million grains of sand

to figure out what
the forces are. And so with this, this
is our mock rover.

Again, this back right
wheel is damaged. And so here, if we do nothing,
we veer off to the right

and don't make it to the end. And now, with this
force model, we

can come up with a feedforward
or a feedback controller that keeps us on track, changing
what the other wheels are doing.

We can also use this
to intentionally do weird things with their wheels.

So here, we're trying to
dig a trench in the sand by taking this back right
wheel, turning it at an angle,

spinning it faster. And in this case
in particular, we wanted to get a trench where all
of the sand we were displacing

was piled up on one side, and we
had a clean face on the other. So wherever the sand is piling
up is going to fall back in.

But on the right
side, in that case, we can clearly see the strata
of what the soil looked

like undisturbed. So we have this kind
of trench-shaped model that we can make and predict
based on your driving conditions

what kind of shape,
how deep, how wide, what does the pile up
look like for that?

So some concluding thoughts. Overall, in my lab, we think a

of contact-- how are we touching
the world, and in particular the
discontinuous nature of contact, as well
as uncertainty,

and trying to come
up with methods to handle large uncertainty? Briefly-- yeah, I got time--

So can we look at things

One of the things in particular

They're all bricks with
wheels or legs attached. So what are we missing

Another project that deals a
lot with the uncertainty side. This is-- today was mostly
more about contact--

is learning how to drive

So we'd like to use

So how do we use a lot of
simulation data that's wrong, but it's close--

it's roughly, right?-- within a
little bit of real world data?

And the key idea
here in simulation in the upper left, these
different colored robots all have slightly
different dynamics.

And rather than doing
the standard sim to real thing of just
randomizing all of that

and throwing it
in to one policy, we keep them all
separate, and we train both a dynamics model as
well as a system identification

transformer. And so we're learning both the
space of possible dynamics,

but also how to figure
out where in that space your particular system is. And then online, you need
just a little bit of data

to figure out where
your actual system lies in that dynamic space. So that's the key idea there.

a bouncing ball, it gets smaller and smaller

an infinite number of bounces

to get to 0. And there is a

saltation matrix is this transversality

you need to have
neighboring trajectories all impact the same guard.

to roughly be zero velocity
